awd_titl_txt: The causes of intraspecific variation in recombination in Drosophila
awd_abstract_narration:
Recombination promotes genetic diversity and the continuous adaptation of natural populations to ever-changing biotic and abiotic environments. These well-known advantages of recombination explain why most species reproduce through outcrossing. Significantly less attention has been paid to the fact that recombination rates are themselves a variable and evolving trait. Despite the profound importance of recombination in evolutionary and genetic studies, there is a significant gap in our basic knowledge of within-species natural variation in recombination. The PIs propose to take advantage of the unparalleled genetic and genomic tools available in the model system Drosophila melanogaster to conduct the first comprehensive study of intraspecific variation in recombination, from the description of where and how much recombination rates vary across genomes and among individuals of the same species, to the elucidation of the molecular causes and evolutionary consequences of this variation. 

This study will provide a new paradigm within models of adaptation under suboptimal conditions by investigating a direct mechanistic link between increased recombination and stressful conditions, the very same circumstances where recombination may be most favorable. The PIs also propose a two-pronged approach to increase the participation of women and other underrepresented groups in science and education. They will organize a series of high school seminars, focusing on Evolution as a modern scientific discipline, and create a summer hands-on workshop for future educators. The workshop will focus on evolutionary and genomic concepts, with laboratory experience and experimental activities easily transferrable to secondary education settings. These seminars will enable the participants to confidently discuss contemporary issues related with evolution and modern genomic techniques (e.g., human and primate evolution, personalized medicine, etc.) in their classrooms.

por.por_cntn:
The support from the National Science Foundation allowed us to gain important new insights into a fundamental cellular and evolutionary process: meiotic recombination. In most sexual eukaryotes, recombination between homologous chromosomes during meiosis is required for the proper formation of gametes, and defects in this process often lead to sterility. Evolutionarily, meiosis and recombination generate genetic diversity among individuals, allowing natural populations to continuously compete and adapt to ever-changing biotic and abiotic environments, and prevent the accumulation of harmful mutations. Despite the fundamental role that recombination plays in most biological systems, major questions remain unanswered, particularly regarding the molecular causes of natural variation in recombination rates. Our goal was to generate data to illuminate the genetic and epigenetic (due to aging, environment, etc.) causes of variation in recombination using Drosophila as a model system and focusing on the main source of recombination: meiotic crossovers.

Our earlier work in D. melanogaster generated the first high-resolution, whole-genome landscapes for crossover rates. We have now generated crossover maps in D. melanogaster for different strains (genetic backgrounds) and at different temperatures. We have also generated transcription profiles for these strains and determined the necessary conditions to assess the role of epigenetic factors on crossovers. Additional to the experimental data we initially proposed to obtain, we expanded our studies in several significant ways. We added information on the three-dimensional (3-D) structure of genomes, which has been related to both transcriptional profiles and crossover rates, and developed a novel analytical framework to identify these 3-D structures with a resolution-free approach based on Wavelet Transforms that improves sensitivity and accuracy. Furthermore, we generated high-resolution crossover landscapes from two species of the D. melanogaster clade (D. yakuba and D. santomea) to provide an evolutionary context for the crossover data in the model species D. melanogaster. These studies provide the first evidence that there is an active mechanism in Drosophila meiosis under natural conditions that favors the transfer of genomes with the highest number of crossover events to the next generation without the need to increase the overall number of meiotic crossover events, thus favoring adaptive evolution. All these datasets generate synergistic information and provide essential insights for future studies to assess the relative role of genetics and the environment (i.e., nature vs. nurture) in adaptive processes.

This funding supported multiple mentoring, outreach, and educational activities. We organized a summer workshop for future educators to fill the gap in modern evolutionary and genomic concepts, targeting teachers of high schools and community colleges near Iowa City (IA). Our project has also contributed to the academic and scientific development of graduate and undergraduate students in STEM-related disciplines, with an emphasis on modern genomics, population genetics and bioinformatics.
